intro: Gilia aggregata subvar. arizonica, commonly known as Arizona gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that range in color from pink to red. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, such as sandy soils and rocky slopes. It produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds, which are dispersed by wind. The plant is often used in xeriscaping due to its drought tolerance and ornamental value.
